isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - MAJOR STRUCTURAL REPAIR: 9600 - REPAIRING CO-9670 CABS

svcproc.title: REPAIRING CO-9670 CABS
svcproc.para: In order to develop the preceding major structural repair instructions we did the actual work on two damaged CO 9670 cabs. The following photographs show this process. Both cabs were damaged as the result of jackknife accidents. Cab A was damaged badly enough so that the engine tunnel had to be removed and replaced. Cab B suffered less extensive damage and was repaired without removing the tunnel. The work was done in a commercial body shop by two regular employees. Neither of them had any special training in the repair of these cabs. Neither of them had worked on a CO 9670 cab before. According to both men, the construction and design of these cabs made their jobs very easy. Neither one encountered any difficulties.

CAB A. Figure 10: This cab was badly damaged on the right rear corner. The force of the blow also buckled the engine tunnel and caused minor damage to other structures as well. It was necessary to remove the tunnel to properly repair this cab. To show how extensive damage can be easily repaired, the whole right floor assembly was also removed. Normally, the damage could have been repaired by splicing on a new right rear outer sill section and some new flooring

figure.caption: Figure 10. Cab A, Right Rear Corner Damage

svcproc.para: CAB B, Figure 11: This cab was hit more in the rear. The rear horse collar and the right rear outer sill were damaged. The impact caused some distortion of the tunnel and some minor damage to other structures. It was decided that this cab could be repaired without removing the tunnel. This proved to be true.

figure.caption: Figure 11. Cab B, Rear Horse Collar Damage

svcproc.para: CAB A, Figure 12: With the side and rear panels removed, the interior damage to the right rear corner can be seen. The force of the blow carried across the cab causing the tunnel to buckle. The left "B" pillar was damaged and the driver's door was sprung outward.

figure.caption: Figure 12. Cab A, Side and Rear Panels Removed

svcproc.para: CAB B, Figure 13: With the rear panel removed, you can see how the force of the blow bent the horse collar out of shape. The right rear outer sill was also bent. The force of the blow caused minor damage at other places in the cab, but most of the damage was located in the rear. The tunnel on this cab did not have to be replaced.

figure.caption: Figure 13. Cab B, Side with Rear Panel Removed

svcproc.para: CAB A, Figure 14: This picture shows how badly the tunnel was buckled. The dashboards have been removed so that the tunnel could be removed from the front horse collar.

figure.caption: Figure 14. Cab A, Buckled Tunnel

svcproc.para: CAB B, Figure 15: With only the back and right quarter panels removed, a pulling bar is set up to straighten the cab as much as possible. The bar is placed along the direction of the impact. The forward end of the pull is fastened to a plate that is attached to the bolts that hold the left front pivot.

figure.caption: Figure 15. Cab B, Back and Right Quarter Panels Removed

svcproc.para: CAB A, Figure 16: After the back and right rear quarter panels were removed, the tunnel was disassembled. The damaged right floor could have been repaired by splicing on a new section of outer sill and floor panel. It was decided to drop the whole floor in order to see if this made the repair more difficult. It did not cause any problems. The picture shows the floor being separated from the horse collar. Note the roof support and the pull that help hold the cab's shape.

figure.caption: Figure 16. Cab A, Tunnel Disassembly

svcproc.para: CAB B, Figure 17: This picture shows the other end of the pulling bar. It has been attached to the upper right corner of the rear horse collar. A jack has been placed to keep the lower corners of the horse collar the correct distance apart. Another pull (not visible) runs on the opposite diagonal to the pulling bar. The two pulls and the jack were tensioned until the diagonal underbody dimensions were correct. With everything still in tension, the tunnel was hammered back into shape.

figure.caption: Figure 17. Cab B, Pulling Bar at Right Corner - Horse Collar

svcproc.para: CAB A, Figure 18: Here is the new outer sill being attached to the old inner rail and floor beams.

figure.caption: Figure 18. Cab A, New Outer Sill

svcproc.para: CAB B, Figure 19: Once the tunnel d been hammered into shape, the rear horse collar was dropped out. You can see that the rear end of the tunnel has taken its correct shape. A jack and a pull hold the rear end of the tunnel in place. Note that the driver's door is sprung out. The top of the cab sprung to the left, then snapped back to the right. Another set of pulls will be used to realign it.

figure.caption: Figure 19. Cab B, Re-Aligning Cab

svcproc.para: CAB A, Figure 20: Here is the new floor panel welded to the repaired floor. Although care was taken to prevent heat build up, the plug welding did cause some distortion of the panel. Huck bolts or rivets could be used to avoid this problem.

figure.caption: Figure 20. Cab A, Floor Panel

svcproc.para: CAB B, Figure 21: A new section of sill is ready to be installed.

figure.caption: Figure 21. Cab B, Section of Sill

svcproc.para: CAB A, Figure 22: The new floor has been attached to the horse collar and the door frame.

figure.caption: Figure 22. Cab A, Floor Attached to Horse Collar and Sill

svcproc.para: CAB B, Figure 23: This picture shows the new section of sill spliced in. The joint is welded and there is a plate backing up the joint and held in place by huck bolts.

figure.caption: Figure 23. Cab B, Sill Spliced In

svcproc.para: CAB A, Figure 24: The right tunnel section has been installed.

figure.caption: Figure 24. Cab A, Right Tunnel Section Installation

svcproc.para: CAB B, Figure 25: A small section of new drip rail is spliced on.

figure.caption: Figure 25. Cab B, Drip Rail Spliced In

svcproc.para: CAB A, Figure 26: The new horse collar is put in place and dropped down while the new tunnel pieces are being fitted. It will be lifted up after the tunnel has been fastened to the inner rails.

figure.caption: Figure 26. Cab A, Horse Collar Installation

svcproc.para: CAB B, Figure 27 : The new horse collar is in place and the cab is ready for fitting the rear panel.

figure.caption: Figure 27. Cab B, Cab Ready for Rear Panel

svcproc.para: CAB A, Figure 28: The floor has been fastened to the horse collar with two 5/16" grade #8 bolts and two 1/4" huck bolts following the rules in the repair section of this service manual.

figure.caption: Figure 28. Cab A, Fastening Floor to Horse Collar

svcproc.para: CAB B, Figure 29: Fitting the rear panel.

figure.caption: Figure 29. Fitting the Rear Panel

svcproc.para: CAB A, Figure 30: This shows the gusset at the left front end of the tunnel. This is a point of great stress and fasteners need to be used that meet current specifications. There is a special illustration of this area in the repair section of this service manual.

figure.caption: Figure 30. Cab A, Gusset at Left Front End of Tunnel

svcproc.para: CAB B, Figure 31: With the back panel held in place with clamps, pulls are used to bring the top of the cab in line.

figure.caption: Figure 31. Cab B, Installation of Top of Cab

svcproc.para: CAB A, Figure 32: The horse collar has been raised into position. Huck bolts were used on the sides of the horse collar and down the center of the tunnel. Plug welds were used across the top of the horse collar where the bunk floor rests. This cab did not require any pulling to bring it back to shape because so much of the structure was replaced. The new pieces fitted together easily.

figure.caption: Figure 32. Cab A, Installation of Horse Collar

svcproc.para: CAB B, Figure 33: The inner surfaces have been painted and the new outer panels can now be installed.

figure.caption: Figure 33. Cab B, Inner Surface Painted

svcproc.para: CAB A, Figure 34: Repairs completed.

figure.caption: Figure 34. Cab A, Repairs Completed

svcproc.para: CAB B, Figure 35: Repairs completed.

figure.caption: Figure 35. Cab B, Repairs Completed
